newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee ends off peaks, still within range.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee ends off peaks, still within range.

text.p: LIFFE robusta coffee futures stepped back from their peaks after earlier trade and speculative buying encountered origin sales but prices still closed firmer.
Price movements were kept in a $20-$30 band after a lacklustre session with the market still battling to steer away from its current $1,610-$1,675 range.
Even a renewed ascent in New York in early trading and news of a possible national port workers strike in Brazil failed to inspire trading.
By the finish, May was just $27 firmer at $1,641 a tonne after ranging between $1,668 and $1,640.
Traders said the contract seemed to be consolidating after falling to a low of $1,515 last week. But they said a move further towards the $1,700 region could be an uphill task for now.
Volume leader July was $38 higher at $1,660. The second-position attracted some switch trades with May and forward September.
New York's May arabica futures hit a session high of $2.00 on Wednesday on further speculative buying.
While the possible Brazilian strike would have no or little immediate impact on the market, players are jittery in case the supply pipelines are affected.
The president of Brazil's Stevedores Federation said stevedores would definitely hold a national strike from 0700 local/1000 GMT on April 4 over a labour dispute.

The latest International Coffee Organization (ICO) export data, as expected, showed that coffee exports continued to be front-loaded as Central and South American producers took advantage of the recent price rally to unload their holdings.
As such, growers would have little coffee left to sell before the next crop harvest later this year.
The ICO said its exporting members' exports rose to 7.41 million 60-kg bags in February from 6.87 million in January and 6.66 million in February 1996.
In the first five months of the current 1996/97 coffee year to February total exports were up at 34.26 million from 30.30 million in the same 1995/96 period.
